fields.description:
h3. Summary

Trying to clone a repo within a project with the "SCM" slug fails.


h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Set up a Stash instance with a project key {{SCM}} or {{REST}}
# Try to clone a repo from that project

h3. Expected Results

It should work (i.e. Stash 3.4.0)

{noformat}
$ git clone http://admin@localhost:7990/stash/scm/scm/rep_1.git
Cloning into 'rep_1'...
remote: Counting objects: 79, done.
remote: Compressing objects: 100% (47/47), done.
remote: Total 79 (delta 14), reused 0 (delta 0)
Unpacking objects: 100% (79/79), done.
Checking connectivity... done.
{noformat}

h3. Actual Results
On Stash 3.10.2 it doesn't and the following output is shown:
{noformat}
$ git clone http://admin@localhost:7990/stash/scm/scm/rep_1.git
Cloning into 'rep_1'...
fatal: remote error: Repository does not exist
The requested repository does not exist, or you do not have permission to
access it.
{noformat}
 
h3.Solution / Workaround
Disable the "Stream Guard" plugin and perform a new clone.
fields.summary: Accessing repositories in a project with key SCM fails

fields.description:
As a Stash user I want to see the current Data Center node so I can include it in problem reports to my administrator.

As a Stash administrator I want to know the Data Center node where problems occur so I can quickly identify the correct logs.

h3. Problem Definition
When problems arise in a Stash Data Center installation it is difficult to determine which node the problem has affected.  This information is available in HTTP headers but this hard for users to access, adding difficulty for the administrator.

h3. Suggested Solution
Add the current cluster NodeID and NodeName to the footer, similar to JIRA DC, Confluence DC, and stash.atlassian.com.
 
h3. Workaround

For the cluster at stash.atlassian.com a plugin was created that shows the current Node ID in the footer.  This plugin is closed source, not fully tested, and officially not supported.  That said, we used it with Stash 3.10 and 3.11 (not yet released) for over a year so no problems are expected.

We strongly recommend that you test this plugin in a test or stage environment prior to using it in production.

# Download the [latest plugin version|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/com.atlassian.stash.stash-clustering-info-plugin/versions] from the Atlassian Marketplace.
# Go to *Administration > Add-ons*
# Click the Upload add-on link at the top right side of the page
# Select the Add-on jar file you downloaded using the file chooser
# Click Upload.

The plugin will be installed first to your current node then mirrored to the others in your cluster.

By default the NodeID will be shown which is a difficult to remember GUID.  You can give each node a human-readable name via this JVM startup parameter:

{code:borderStyle=solid}
-Dcluster.node.name=DESIRED_NODE_NAME
{code}
fields.summary: Display the name and ID of the current Stash Data Center node in page footer

fields.description:
As a Stash administrator I would like to create Stash groups and populate those groups with users from our LDAP directory. However our LDAP directory is a read-only directory and when I attempt to add a user from that directory into the group created in the Stash directory I get an error that read-only directory entries can't be added to the group.  I can add users that are in the Stash directory to the group so the group is writable. 

Without this capability I always need to go back to our IT department to create and manage groups that are used in Stash.
fields.summary: Add users from read-only directory to Stash managed groups

fields.description:
Synchronising with an a directory server where a "User Unique ID Attribute" is not available will result in users unable to log in, and the following error in the Stash logs:

{noformat}
ERROR: duplicate key value violates unique constraint "uq_cwd_user_dir_ext_id"
{noformat}

This new constraint was added in STASH-5244, however relies on the {{external_id}} column in the {{cwd_user}} table being populated with a NULL in the case no "User Unique ID Attribute" (typically {{entryUUID}}) is provided by the directory server.

This problem is occurring because, when the required attribute is missing from the directory server response, an empty string is inserted into the {{external_id}} column rather than NULL.

*Work Around*
Ideally an external id (such as a UUID) should be provided to Stash by the directory server. This permits renaming of users. LDAP servers should provide an attribute 'entryUUID' according to RFC 4530. In some cases this is provided via a different attribute, and Stash should be configured to use this attribute. Some details of this can be found here: https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/STASH/Connecting+Stash+to+an+existing+LDAP+directory

The setting can be found as follows for LDAP servers:
# Go to {{Administration >> User Directories}}
# Click Edit on the LDAP server
# Go to User Schema Settings >> User Unique ID Attribute
# Update this to the correct attribute then click "Save and Test"

*Reproducing the problem*
Configure an LDAP Directory server as per normal, but instead change the "User Unique ID Attribute" (see above section for how to locate that setting) to some random string that will not be a valid entry attribute. Once synchronisation is complete, inspect the {{cwd_user}} table and note a single user for that directory has been inserted and has an empty string in the {{external_id}} column.

*The fix*
Ensure a null gets inserted into the external_id column, rather than an empty string. Then the constraint will be happy.
fields.summary: ERROR: duplicate key value violates unique constraint "uq_cwd_user_dir_ext_id"

fields.description:
When typing the name of a user, it is very very useful to be able to say "Fred Bloggs" and have it match "Frederick Bloggs", especially if other systems display this user's first name as "Fred". Right now, "Fred Bloggs" matches no users at all, and forces me to remember that on Stash, Fred has a longer name, go back and type out more of Fred's first name before I can get a match.

The same goes for "Steve" and "Steven", or "Ben" and "Benjamin" - common prefixes of common longer first names.

I'm going to leave the "Steve" and "Stephen" variant to another issue, since that requires much smarter name stemming than needed for the simple case above.
fields.summary: Make user autocomplete accept prefixes of first name and last name

fields.description:
We have 38708 users in Crowd and ~ 1500 in both Jira and Confluence, but only 100 active in Stash (about to go to 250). In Jira/Conf - only the users who have access to the application show when trying to manage users in the admin, however in Stash, we get ALL users in the admin list and have to go into each account to see if they're flagged as a Stash User.

The directory for Stash is Crowd, using it's own Application with False for allow users from any group, and only the group stash-users as permitted to login.

Not too fussed if all users show up (though it is different to other apps), but a nice simple way of seeing JUST the Stash enabled users would be great.
fields.summary: User management - filtering to just active (licensed) Bitbucket users

fields.description:
Situation: 
1) There are commits on branch A that make some changes. A PR is opened into a target branch
2) There are commits on branch B that make the same changes. A PR is opened into a target branch
3) Branch B gets merged into the target branch. 
4) Viewing the PR for branch A will show no changes in the diff, but the PR will not be marked as merged.

This is a confusing situation and should probably explain that the reason the PR is not merged is that it contains commits that do not exist in the source branch, even though the exact same changes have been made.
fields.summary: Make message clearer when diff is empty but PR is still open

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
 The merge conflict resolution instructions are not very helpful for cross repository pull requests. They can also give instructions that the user simply cannot fulfil because of lack of permissions.

h3. Suggested Solution
* if the pull request is created because of an auto-merge failure, show the auto-merge conflict resolution instructions.
* if the source branch is a feature, bugfix or hotfix branch, show the old merge instructions that tells the user to merge the target branch back into the source branch and resolve the conflicts.
* If the source branch is a release branch, the production branch or the main development branch, tell the user to manually merge the pull request.
* If we cannot determine the type of the release branch, err on the side of caution and tell the user to manually merge the pull request.

Currently, different instructions are given in different circumstances

The goal of this logic is to not provide potentially dangerous merge instructions as described in STASH-5443.

However, consider cross repository pull requests where the pull request author wants to contribute changes from his/her fork to the main repository. In these cases, the author may not have permissions to manually merge the pull request in the target repository. Likewise, the maintainer of the central repository may not have access to the fork and cannot resolve the conflicts. 

For cross repository pull requests it should always be safe to merge the target branch back into the source branch and update the pull request. For cross repository pull requests, the onus should be on the contributor to resolve the conflicts.

That leaves the question of permissions. If the current user does not have sufficient permissions to resolve the conflicts, the instructions should reflect this. Perhaps they could say something like "The pull request is conflicted and cannot be merged. <Pull request author> will need to resolve the conflicts before it can be merged"
fields.summary: Improve merge conflict resolution instructions

fields.description:
I'm trying to trigger a simple build/deploy script on commit to one of our Stash repositories.

I know that if we were running a straight git repo (i.e. not Stash), all I would need to do would be to add it as a post-receive script to the hooks folder for the repo, and I'd be done and onto the next job. For example, in this case, I just want to do something as simple as this...

curl -S http://www.myserver.com/trigger-my-deployment?token=mysecrettoken

Unfortunately, it seems the Atlassian devs deemed that Stash admins would not understand or want to be able to do this?!...

https://blogs.atlassian.com/2013/03/stash-git-hooks-api/

I strongly disagree! Stash should be making git repo admin easier, not harder. The way it is now, what is a simple 4-5 minute job in straight git, that ought to be a 1-2 minute job with Stash is just not as straightforward as it could be. Currently, I am faced with having to scrub up my rusty Java skills, break out a dev environment, and spend a considerable amount of time writing/debugging/testing/deploying a whole bunch of custom Java code.

IMHO, there should be a standard Atlassian plugin, provided by default with Stash, that provides a very simple 'Script' hook that allows us to run snippets of shell script, a bit like how Bamboo/Jenkins works. Simple. Generic. Effective.

I've hunted through the marketplace for a third party plugin that does this, but I could find one and I really don't feel I should have to for such a basic requirement. It should be a default capability. Stash should be extending git's functionality, not stubbing it.
fields.summary: Simple post-receive hooks impossible
border added around images in markdown

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Trying to clone a repo within a project with the {{SCM}} or {{REST}} slug fails.


h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Set up a Stash instance with a project key {{SCM}} or {{REST}}
# Try to clone a repo from that project

h3. Expected Results

It should work (i.e. Stash 3.4.0)

{noformat}
$ git clone http://admin@localhost:7990/stash/scm/scm/rep_1.git
Cloning into 'rep_1'...
remote: Counting objects: 79, done.
remote: Compressing objects: 100% (47/47), done.
remote: Total 79 (delta 14), reused 0 (delta 0)
Unpacking objects: 100% (79/79), done.
Checking connectivity... done.
{noformat}

h3. Actual Results
On Stash 3.10.2 it doesn't and the following output is shown:
{noformat}
$ git clone http://admin@localhost:7990/stash/scm/scm/rep_1.git
Cloning into 'rep_1'...
fatal: remote error: Repository does not exist
The requested repository does not exist, or you do not have permission to
access it.
{noformat}
 
h3.Solution / Workaround
Disable the "Stream Guard" plugin and perform a new clone.
fields.summary: Accessing repositories in a project with key SCM fails

fields.description:
Currently, there is an option to send notifications for pushing commits but we're only interested in commits that are pushed to an open PR.

I'd suggest adding an option in the HipChat config for a brunch under pull requests for *updates*. It could then send a notification along the lines of

{noformat}
Pull request <PR Name> updated by <User> in <Repo>. 2 commits pushed.
- Commit 1
- Commit 2
{noformat}

This could also cross over with my suggestion in STASH-7550 by adding an @-mention for the assigned reviewers (or possibly just the assigned reviewers who are yet to approve).

fields.description:
When Stash sends a HipChat notification about a newly created pull request, I'd like to see it @-mention the specified reviewers so they get a notification.

The new HipChat integration saves us manually copy-pasting the URL to the pull request into Stash, but we still need to manually send another message with the reviewers in it so they get a notification.

fields.description:
In Stash 3.10.2, following the "Unable to access your account?" link from the Stash login page, the behaviour is different for a delegated vs synced LDAP directory.

For a synced LDAP, entering an LDAP username on the /passwordreset page gets a (correct) error that "Your account details are read-only. Please contact your administrator to change your password."

However, this doesn't occur for a delegated LDAP user - instead, the password reset email is sent, but when following the link and choosing a new password the page just gives a generic 'Could not update password for bradley.baetz' error. This leads to user confusion.

The same behaviour should occur for both types of LDAP user directories.
fields.summary: Disable "reset your password" option for delegated LDAP

fields.description:
We have stash setup with a large set of reviewers, and with 2 approvals required to merge a change.  We have had situations where an issue has been found, a comment raised, and the pull request has been merged without remediation of the issue raised by the commenter.

It would be useful if a reviewer could put a block on a pull request.  This would prevent a request being merged as a result of the issue raised.  This isn't as severe as declining the pull request which would lose all the comments raised around the change and it's history.
fields.summary: Allow a reviewer to Block a pull request

fields.description:
*Scenario:*
# Hundreds of projects, and hundreds of repositories in each project
# A new group of users is created
# You want to grant, e.g., read-only access to this group to all repositories

*Problem:*
It is very hard to achieve that, because a lot of manual work is required, even if [project permissions|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/STASH/Using+project+permissions] are used.

*Suggestion:*
There should be an option to grant read-only access at the global level.

*Workaround:*
A script can be developed to make use of the available REST endpoints:
# Call {{GET}} [/rest/api/1.0/projects|https://developer.atlassian.com/static/rest/stash/3.10.2/stash-rest.html#idp1759552] in order to retrieve a list of projects;
# Iterate over the project names, calling {{PUT}} [/rest/api/1.0/projects/\{projectKey\}/permissions/groups|https://developer.atlassian.com/static/rest/stash/3.10.2/stash-rest.html#idp3392768] and grant {{PROJECT_READ}} permission to the group created.
fields.summary: Allow granting access to projects at global level.

fields.description:
A plugin that provides an SSO authentication handler can get into the following redirect-loop:

* User navigates to https://stash.yourcompany.com/any/page
* SSO authentication handler is called, looks up the user, finds it and returns it
* Stash's authentication stack checks whether the user is licensed, discovers it is not and throws an AuthenticationException
* A redirect to /login is sent to the user
* SSO authentication handler is called again, etc

The reason behind this behaviour is that when you log in with a username / password and you're not licensed, you end up on the login screen with an error message explaining why you can't log in.

*Workaround*
The SSO authentication handler should check whether the user is licensed and return {{null}} if the user is not.
fields.summary: token-based (sso) authentication handlers trigger a redirect loop when returning an unlicensed user

fields.description:
See [Fork Syncing is Slow|https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/17905469/fork-syncing-is-slow]

I am creating this feature suggestion after Bryan's response. It would be nice to be able to modify the delay of when forks are synced. Currently, it's set to 30 seconds to help alleviate server loading. However, if the server is not heavily being used, it may make sense in some cases to reduce the fork syncing delay time.

fields.description:
As a administrator i would like to be able to create & write hooks which intercept all modifications to a repository from users with the write permission. Currently i can use RepositoryMergeRequestCheck and PreReceiveRepositoryHook to stop merge requests and requests from git clients. 

However if i want to stop users from:
*  deleting certain branches (e.g. depending on the last commit to the branch)
*  creating branches with certain names
*  Verify commits & commit messages for commits created trough the gui.
*  and other operations in the gui that writes to the repository in any way
I have not found a possible way to examine the proposed change in a script/addon and disallow it.

On a "normal" git server all interaction with the repo is channeled trough the pre-recieve hook, and i would like to have one or more hooks to cover all operations available in the stash gui that can modify the repository so i can make sure all users with write permission (i.e. not admin) to the repository cannot do operations not allowed by the hooks in any way.
fields.summary: Hooks for all gui operations

fields.description:
Currently the {{notification inbox}} (or whatever it's called) icon will show the number of PR that is waiting to be reviewed, and that is great. Email flying around and it really helps to focus on what PR still outstanding and action accordingly.
However, the ones that you created and waiting for others to review, it is no reminder visible, unless you go into the {{notification inbox}} and click {{Created}} tab.

For my use case, my project team decides that if the PR is created from internal to the team then we leave it for the requester to perform the merge. We have some "auto-approvers", and at times we want key reviewer to approve prior to merging, hence this decision.

Another use case, pull request will need to be built successfully prior to merging. sometimes we have build storms where PR build won't be picked up until after half hour, and it is very likely no one remembers to merge it when it is finally built.

Hence suggesting that notification inbox should show number in red circle if there is outstanding PR to review (current state), and if there is nothing to review, then show number in blue circle of the number of PR user has created. Show no number if nothing in both lists.
fields.summary: Show number of unmerged pull request PR you created on the notification inbox

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian status as of July 2020|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#3c78b5|titleBGColor=#3c78b5|bgColor=#e7f4fa}
Hi everyone, 

Thank you for your feedback on this suggestion. In [Bitbucket Server and Data Center 7.5|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/bitbucket-server-7-5-release-notes-1018760416.html#BitbucketServer7.5releasenotes-hiddencomments] we have added the ability to view file’s activity stream showing comments that are outdated or appear on another diff (for that specific file). Just click on the _other comments counter_ when it appears on a file in your pull request.

Give it a try and let us know how it goes.

Cheers,
 Imran Khan 
 Product Manager - Bitbucket Server and Data Center
{panel}
 

*Original description:*

(Related to STASH-3263; my concern is slightly different; for internal reference see SSP-9230)

The comments in a PR diff disappear (Stash marks them as "outdated") when a new commit has been added to the source branch, and the line in question has been edited.

This is a neat feature in some ways, but it makes it nearly impossible to audit whether particular a comment has actually been addressed. Sometimes a changed line doesn't actually fix the relevant comment.

We have just been doing code reviews with HUNDREDS of minor comments, and a lot of them are gone unless I wade through the hundreds of comments in the activity stream to see if they are addressed.

I think the common issue between this and STASH-3263 is that comments need to be "attached" somehow to a specific immutable item in Stash, so as changes occur, the comments do not disappear, and can be found again.

How they are best presented in the context of a pull request, where the subject of a pull request is changing dynamically, is I guess the point of STASH-3263. If implemented, that would probably serve this purpose (though it seems rather complex, and having to wait for that to be fully implemented is kind of a downside).

There needs to be a way to browse *all* outstanding comments, even if they are "outdated", to make sure they were addressed. I found that I could get to them via the PR Activity stream on the overview page, but with hundreds of comments it is very difficult to manage, and there's no way to unambiguously refer to one comment in question if it is "outdated"; you have to wade through the hundreds of comments first until you get to the one you are looking for.

A coworker and I just wasted about an hour of time each, essentially re-doing the review for a couple of files, because of this problem.
fields.summary: Please don't "bury" PR comments just because the relevant lines have changed and they are "outdated"

fields.description: The "Network" tab appears to show only the graph for the most recent changeset. I have created a repo with some disconnected components (used subgit in my case, but you should be able to do the same thing with {{git checkout -b --orphan}} ), and it does not show the main graph.

fields.description:
As a developer that creates forks of many repositories across many projects it would be useful to duplicate the project organization in my personal profile.

For example if I have three projects with 3 repositories each in Stash it would be helpful for me to organize these projects and repositories in a layout that is similar to what is on the project page.

Also I have found that with submodules, I can use a relative path but that only works for submodules that are at the same relative location.  When using submodules across projects they work fine but if I fork the submodule, only those in my personal space that are from the same project fork correct (come from my profile).  

This request is similar to https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/STASH-2468
fields.summary: Allow Projects in personal space

fields.description:
When the branch permissions plugin stores a group, it stores the groups as lower-case.

fields.summary: Groups are transformed to lowercase in branch permissions

fields.description:
There seems to be no method to rollup the configuration of hooks across an instance.

As a workaround, this SQL query will provide this capability:
{code}
SELECT
    p.name AS project_name,
    r.name AS repository_name,
    s.hook_key
FROM
    sta_repo_hook s
INNER JOIN
    repository r
ON
    s.repository_id = r.id
INNER JOIN
    project p
ON
    r.project_id = p.id
WHERE
    s.is_enabled = 't'
ORDER BY
    p.name,
    r.name ;
{code}

It would be good for this to be available in the UI and from an API standpoint to assist administrators with their audit/security/compliance needs.
fields.summary: Provide capability for instance-wide hook report

fields.description:
Desired:
Domain.com/rest/latest/admin/groups/more-repositories?context&filter

Behavior:
Given a context of a groupname, return all projects and repositories that the group has access to , as well as access levels.

Workaround:
For all projects/repositories in instance, iterate and request 
/rest/api/1.0/projects/{projectKey}/permissions/groups
and for each repository
/rest/api/1.0/projects/{projectKey}/repos/{repositorySlug}/permissions/groups?filter
fields.summary: Permissions Audit: Create API endpoints that returns Projects and Repos a particular group has access to

fields.description:
We are running stash 3.6 I reviewed the release notes from 3.10 down aswell as jira and didn't find anything related.

The pull request diff view seen before the pull request is created looks like the three dot version of C git diff.  

i.e. git diff $(git merge-base A B) B

It is showing the changes along the B branch since the merge point which give an indication of what will be merged into A.

For our project that uses cherry picks we are really much more interested in the two dot version:

i.e. git diff A B

In our scenario we have a develop branch where development occurs.  At some point we create a release branch from it and then cherry pick a few changes that can go to the production release.

So at this point all of the changes in release are in develop its just that they have been cherry-picked instead of merged.

Post release we want to merge the release branch down into develop.

When we create the pull request the diff in the preview is showing the diff of all of the cherry picked commits.

When the pull request is created the diff changes to show what we want which is a diff of the head of the develop branch and the head of the release branch (in our case no changes).

We'd like to have an option in the repository settings to change the preview mode from three dot to two dot.  

Another way would be to have a way to set the preference on a branch by branch basis. 

i.e. if you are making a pull request from the release branch then use two dot diff instead of the three dot diff.
fields.summary: Configurable Pull Request Diff Mode (two dot vs three dot diff mode)

fields.description: BranchPermissionService does not required ADMIN before. Since 3.10 it failed.
fields.summary: BranchPermissionService.findUnauthorizedRefs shouldn't require REPO_ADMIN permission

fields.description:
It would be great to have a REST endpoint to monitor the status of Crowd / LDAP replication.
This would allow customers to monitor if its been too long since the last successful synchronisation.

Crowd seems to have some REST APIs that would let customers do that, but this does not seem to be possible in Stash yet.

This information can be retrieved through a DB query:
{code:sql}
select * from cwd_directory_attribute where attribute_name = 'com.atlassian.crowd.directory.sync.laststartsynctime'
{code}
The time is shown in milliseconds.

However it would be nice to have a supported API in order to retrieve that information.
fields.summary: REST API to monitor last external user synchronisation period

fields.description:
A "git clone" stress test of Stash can result in failures under some circumstances. Below are the broad steps used to reproduce this problem:

1) Create an EC2 instance for testing
- Instance Type: c4.8xlarge
- OS: Ubuntu Server 14.04 LTS (HVM), SSD Volume Type - ami-69631053
- Storage: EBS Provisioned SSD 3000 IOPS

2) Install openjdk-7-jdk and git using apt-get install

3) Install Stash 3.9.2 via installer

4) Create a repository with a clone of the Linux kernel

5) Restart Stash (Why? This will become evident later)

6) Execute, locally on the same server as Stash, 20 concurrent git clones of the repository. These need to be executed at the same instant so a script like this works best:

{code}
#!/bin/bash
for i in $(seq 1 20)
do
    git clone http://localhost:7990/scm/project/linux-clone.git linux$i > log$i 2>&1 &
done
{code}

The result will be some clones run successfully to completion and some hang (apparently forever). The atlassian-stash-access.log will show evidence of the same, for example the failed clones will result in the following entries (note the second last column indicates the failed clones failed very quickly):

{noformat}

Other observations about the problem:

* This only occurs when the load test is executed immediately after starting Stash. Subsequent runs of the test after the first failed one, do succeed. Also, running a single {{git clone}} prior to executing the testcase will result in the testcase succeeding.

* Have not been able to reproduce the problem when the SCM upload-pack cache is disabled. I did so using the REST interface:
{{curl -v -u adminuser:password -X PUT localhost:7990/rest/scm-cache/latest/config/upload-pack/enabled/false}}

* Adding a one second sleep in the loop that forks the "git clone" operations (that is put a delay between the start of each clone) the problem does not occur. Even adding a 200ms delay appears to avoid the problem

* The problem can be reproduced using HTTP but not SSH

* Problem can be reproduced with the git clients either running locally or remotely

* The number of successful versus failed clones varies. Have seen failures in the range 7-16 of 20.
fields.summary: Git clone hang during stress test

fields.description:
I have a PR that include dozens of new files. The Diff view appears fine, but when I use the search tool in the Diff tab, it stops after a certain point, and does not find anything in files after that point even though the text being searched for is there.

In my case I can find text in the first 142 files or so, but not after that point. I am not sure, I lost track of the count. It may be after the first 128 text files since some of the new files are binary.

It doesn't matter whether I search for a line that is only in one file, or a line like `(c)` that is in dozens of files, it always stops at the same point

------

I can't share the repository I mentioned above, but I can reproduce the issue in another test case, which I've put up on Bitbucket:

- see https://bitbucket.org/jason_s/stash-7517/ 
- clone it into a Stash instance, 
- open repos/stash-7517/commits/bc1efc88e4f528766273073588d6474b00dc2769
- verify that all 500 files in the {{output}} directory are visible
- most (if not all) files should contain the word "frumious" -- verify that files {{496_borogoves.txt}} and {{497_chortled.txt}} contain the word "frumious"
- search for "frumious" and look for the last file in the list. In my Stash server, running Stash r3.4.0, the last file shown is {{187_jabberwock.txt}}

!stash-7517.png!

- verify that "frumious bandersnatch" exists in files {{463_brillig.txt}} and {{484_callay.txt}}
- search for "frumious bandersnatch" and look for the last file in the list. In my Stash server, the last file shown is {{176_burbled.txt}}

!stash-7517-2.png!
fields.summary: Diff code search stops after a certain # of files

fields.description:
# Go to stash (eg http://localhost:7990/stash/, redirects to http://localhost:7990/stash/login?next=/projects)
# Leave either the username or password field blank
# Click the login button

Expected results: "Invalid username or password." error message
Actual results: Redirected to http://localhost:7990/stash/j_stash_security_check which gives a 404 error page

Logging in with an incorrect username/password (but not blank) does give the expected result error message.

This is with only a local directory, in stash 3.10.0. It works on stash 3.6.1
fields.summary: Trying to log in with a blank username or password gives 404 page
comments using backtick Markdown to indicate verbatim inline code snippets do not respect spaces
Stash Backup Client does not allow for special characters

fields.description: The REST endpoint "/permitted" in the v1.0 api for branch permissions returns no results, despite there being permissions with users and/or groups specified.
fields.summary: Branch permissions v1 REST endpoint "permitted" not working

fields.description:
See attached, the merge to branch is clipped. The only way to see the whole branch name is to hover over, then wait. I'd much rather have the branch name expanded, especially given there's a whole bunch of open space.

!Screen Shot 2015-06-17 at 3.32.23 PM.png!
fields.summary: Don't truncate target branch on pull request page

fields.description: Using the REST API {code}http://mystash:7990/rest/branch-permissions/1.0/projects/{projectKey}/repos/{repositoryBlob}/permitted {code} should return a paged list of users and groups who have been given permissions to the stated repository.  However the response is always  {code}{"size":0,"limit":5000,"isLastPage":true,"values":[],"start":0}{code}
fields.summary: The permitted endpoint in the Rest API is returning 0 results when it should return a list of users/groups who have been given permission to the repository
Stash branch-utils REST API documentation has typo in example

fields.description:
h2. Atlassian update: 13-dec-2019

Thanks for your feedback on this suggestion. [Bitbucket Server and Data Center 6.9|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/bitbucket-server-6-9-release-notes-980462706.html] onwards if committer and author were different, both of their avatars will be displayed on the commit. Hovering on the avatar you will be able to see the committed/authored date.
h2. Original description: 

Hello,

We would find it very useful to have the possibility to see and order on authored date as well as commit date in the commit list view. We use cherry pick a lot and we would like to be able to see the difference between those dates, to see when someone actually picked a certain commit.

Any feedback would be greatly appreciated.

tx
fields.summary: Display both authored and commit date in the commit view

fields.description:
When navigating to a project that does not exist, Stash currently returns a 200 HTTP response code. Since the project does not exists, a 404 response code should be returned instead.

{code}curl -i -u <USER> http://jeff.local/projects/NOPE
HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Server: Apache-Coyote/1.1
X-AREQUESTID: @1OX7SGRx198x1832x0
X-AUSERNAME: user
X-AUSERID: 101
X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block
X-Frame-Options: SAMEORIGIN
X-Content-Type-Options: nosniff
Pragma: no-cache
Expires: Thu, 01 Jan 1970 00:00:00 GMT
Cache-Control: no-cache
Cache-Control: no-store
Content-Type: text/html;charset=UTF-8
Content-Language: en-US
Transfer-Encoding: chunked
Vary: Accept-Encoding
Date: Wed, 17 Jun 2015 03:18:27 GMT

<!DOCTYPE html><html lang="en"><head><meta charset="utf-8"><meta http-equiv="X-UA-Compatible" content="IE=edge"><title>Project not found - Stash</title>
...{code}
fields.summary: Project not found page should return 404 response code, currently returns 200

fields.description:
The "Prevent changes without a pull request" branch permission in stash 3.10 doesn't stop an initial commit to a matching branch. To reproduce:

* Create a pattern restriction on refs/heads/release/** with the "Prevent changes without a pull request" checkbox checked
* git clone http://admin@localhost:7990/stash/scm/project_1/rep_1.git
* cd rep_1
* git checkout -b release/1.2.3
* echo "TEST" > README
* git add README; git commit -m TEST README
* git push (this succeeds, but should fail)
* echo "TEST2" >> README; git commit -m TEST2 README
* git push (this fails, as expected)

I'm not sure if this is intentional - the branch has to be created somehow in order to do the pull request, but allowing brand new commits as part of the creation seems wrong.
fields.summary: "Prevent changes without a pull request" restriction doesn't prevent initial commit

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:

1. Connect an AD with Stash via JIRA/Crowd and synchronise all the users across JIRA/Crowd and Stash

2. Rename a user in AD and sync across JIRA/Crowd and Stash

3. Upon sync to Stash, Stash creates another user as per screenshot
!screenshot.png|thumbnail!

4. When trying to logging using the updated username, it gets stuck on /j_stash_security_check with an Error 500

{noformat}

2015-06-16 19:19:51,230 DEBUG [http-nio-7990-exec-3] @9D3RJRx1159x1004x0 oeklth 0:0:0:0:0:0:0:1 "POST /mvc/error500 HTTP/1.1" c.a.s.p.a.c.i.CrowdSsoAuthenticationHandler Skipping Crowd SSO as it is not enabled
2015-06-16 19:19:51,230 DEBUG [http-nio-7990-exec-3] @9D3RJRx1159x1004x0 oeklth 0:0:0:0:0:0:0:1 "POST /mvc/error500 HTTP/1.1" c.a.s.i.s.s.PluginAuthenticationProvider attempting authentication with authenticator com.atlassian.stash.stash-authentication:crowdHttpAuthHandler
2015-06-16 19:19:51,230 DEBUG [http-nio-7990-exec-3] @9D3RJRx1159x1004x0 oeklth 0:0:0:0:0:0:0:1 "POST /mvc/error500 HTTP/1.1" c.a.s.i.user.DefaultUserService Authenticating user: _Stash-JIRA-AD_renam

5. In the cwd_user table, it shows the two users which are active

Recreate the user directory to "refresh" the cwd_user table
fields.summary: Affected users are unable to login to Stash after those users are renamed in AD while connected to Stash via JIRA/Crowd

fields.description:
Instead of checking last-modified headers for project and user avatars, store avatars on the client permanently and use a cache-busting url parameter when the avatar is modified.

This is to prevent the round trip to the server to check for last-modified times.
fields.summary: Permanently cache user and project avatars on the client to reduce the number of calls back to the server to check for last-modified

fields.description:
The new Stash 3.10 rest restriction API (https://developer.atlassian.com/static/rest/stash/3.10.0/stash-branch-permissions-rest.html#idp85904) supports a rest URL (/rest/branch-permissions/2.0/projects/{projectKey}/repos/{repositorySlug}/restrictions) to get/rest repository restrictions.

The POST API supports adding users/groups to be excluded from read-only restrictions, however the GET API doesn't return them - this only seems to be possible using the (deprecated) v1.0 APIs
fields.summary: REST restriction API doesn't allow user to get the allowed users/groups

fields.description:
Stash doesn't let a user create a pull request from using a tag as the source using the UI (get the error "You cannot create a pull request with a tag")

I can't see a reason for the source not being allowed to be a tag (the destination need to be a branch, but not the source) and this does work through the REST API.

Use case is to merge a specific release into a development branch or master after its gone live.
fields.summary: Create pull request starting from a tag through UI

fields.description:
1. For now the search box (the upper right corner one) only matches the repositories whose names start with the keyword, I suggest we should have it match any part of the repository name (like we do a full text indexing against the repository names?).

2. Should have a way to look up repositories by committer.

3. Repository grouping inside a given project.

The above suggested features are extremely useful when using Stash in a publisher-like firm which has tons of repositories in a single Stash server.
fields.summary: more flexible ways to search repositories

fields.description:
h5. Steps to reproduce
1. Receive an email notification from Stash containing a link to a linked instance for which has not been authorised using OAuth.
2. Click the issue link

h5. Expected
Clicking on LEM-800 takes me to the issue on SDOG.

h5. Actual
Clicking on LEM-800 takes me to the OAuth authorisation page on SDOG.
fields.summary: Link to JIRA issue in Stash email points to "oauth authorize" flow

fields.description:
Currently build links only show up after the build is completed in bamboo.

https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/STASH/Checks+for+merging+pull+requests?continue=https%3A%2F%2Fconfluence.atlassian.com%2Fdisplay%2FSTASH%2FChecks%2Bfor%2Bmerging%2Bpull%2Brequests&application=cac

It would be nice if the build link could show up while it is still in progress so it is immediately accessible.
fields.summary: Link to bamboo builds in progress

fields.description:
I went to create a Pull Request. For the target branch dropdown/select menu, it always highlights the first item. I would expect it to highlight the currently selected item.

Example (see attached), "release/maven" is selected, yet when the dropdown expands, it highlights "master", implying that "master" is the current selected item.
fields.summary: Branch dropdown menu highlights wrong item

fields.description:
The following URI would retrieve a page of the latest commits to the test repository in the TEST project on https://mystash.com

https://mystash.com/rest/api/1.0/projects/TEST/repos/test/commits

Just like we can use the query parameters {{limit}} (for number of results per page) and {{start}} (which indicates which item should be used as the first item in the page of results, and expects *a number*), we should have a {{since}} / {{hash}} parameter in which we can specify *a commit hash* and get all the commits on a branch from that hash onwards.
fields.summary: REST API: Allow retrieving commits from a specific hash onwards

fields.description:
We upgraded from 3.50 to 3.10.0

Developers that had existing Branch Permissions on their repositories are now being prevented from pushing to branches that the permissions show they should have write access. The Branch permissions show write access for only 2 groups, the developer in this case actually being part of both groups..
fields.summary: Upgrade to 3.10 breaks existing Branch Permissions

fields.description:
We recently made some incorrect changes to an LDAP group, and Stash disabled pushes as we'd gone over the limit.

However, Stash doesn't actually tell you how many users you have over the limit! See attached screenshots.

We worked around this with the plugin provided at [https://confluence.atlassian.com/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=317949653] but it's not ideal. It doesn't show readable user names, nor a total.

It's particularly confusing after -STASH-2532-, which means users may be listed in permissions when they aren't actually licensed users.

Ideally, Stash would always say how many licensed users there are, and provide a page to see who those users are e.g non-active, recently added etc.
fields.summary: Show how many extra users over the Stash license there are

fields.description: The branch permissions UI is currently not extensible. It would be good to allow plugin developers to easily add custom {{RefMatchers}} to the existing "create branch permission" UI.
fields.summary: Make the branch permissions UI extensible

fields.description: Dev bootstrap talks to Crowd directly whereas the prod bootstrap talks to the UserAdminService. The UserAdminService.createUser(..., addToDefaultGroup) creates the user then does a license check to see if they can be added to the group which causes their permission graph to be loaded and cached and this is not later invalidated because we add permissions in the bootstrap via the DAO (for various reasons).
fields.summary: Admin user created through unattended setup has no perms until server restart
In the From: header in immediate notification emails use the user's name that triggered the event instead of "Stash"

fields.description:
@mentions are great, but the `@` character appears in Java annotations and Python decorators, and when typing code snippets in Stash comments, then Stash tries to find a matching user and incessantly complains "no matching users found".

Please add an ignore feature so that if the @ sign is in a code comment (whether inline or block), it does not try to treat it as an @mention.
fields.summary: ignore @mentions in code snippets

fields.description:
@mentions are great, but the `@` character appears in Java annotations and Python decorators, and when typing code snippets in Stash comments, then Stash tries to find a matching user and incessantly complains "no matching users found".

Please add an ignore feature so that if the @ sign is in a code comment (whether inline or block), it does not try to treat it as an @mention.
fields.summary: ignore @mentions in code snippets

fields.description:
Sometimes, the git repository in Stash is corrupted due to unexpected shutdown.

It would be great to have a "git fsck" function in Stash to identify corrupted file in the repository.
fields.summary: git fsck function in Stash
